body:
This app needs at least an FAQ. I'm certain this app can handle this, but I'm scratching my head at all of the settings. I don't want the app to waste energy scanning. I will turn on my WiFi when I get home, app can ignore turning on compelling. I want the app to turn WiFi off when I walk out of range (lose signal).

How do I do that? Thanks so much!

title: [bug] Spotify is not detected as whitelisted app

Unfortunately, this feature only works if the spotify app is foreground, not if it is running in the background, with music playing. As a result, I need to turn on the screen of my phone between each song, which goes against the utility of your app.

title: Saving more power when not in range of wifi access points
body:
As Android only disables wifi rather than turning it off, is it possible to include a button to actually turn it off (not disable - they are very different things) when it isn't wanted, maybe with some slightly different code, or will it take google to write a new driver?

I don't use wifi on my phone for various reasons. As such I want to be able to turn the wi-fi off completely rather than just disabling it.

I did some tests with a tablet I bought about 2 years ago which was using about 5% of the power over a week even when wifi was disabled. When enabled it used up to 9% of the battery usage over a week, despite not actually using wifi to connect to anything. As battery life was more important to me (and as I used to work in electronics) I removed the wifi chip to see how that improved matters. When the wifi chip was removed the battery life was extended considerably, much more than I expected at the time and more than it should if just in standby.

No apps I have tried (100+ apps over 2 years so far) turn it off properly. No android phones or different OS versions that I have tried turn it off. They all seem to call the same basic android code that everyone uses to disable it instead. (although a friend recently suggested a 'jellykat' rom to try)

BTW: no linux devices I have tried turn it off properly in software either! (Linksys, Dlink, netgear...)
Some Vista and Win7 laptops (Dell, IBM, HP) do if you have the original drivers.
IOS used to turn it off properly up to v4.1. After that they followed the same path as google and disabled it instead. Maybe this change caused the well documented battery life problems in v4.2 onwards?

title: "Schedule off" isn't always received.  Suspect app failing to turn off Wifi.
body:
When I set a delay (10s, 30s, etc), often I don't see the "Alarm received", "Wifi turned off" log entries after the "Scheduling Wifi off" entry.  

It's inconclusive to me whether the wifi is left on in those instances.  I've seen instances when wifi is indeed left on.  I've also seen instances where wifi went away, despite no "Wifi turned off" entry in log.

If I set delay to zero, I would invariably see the whole wifi off sequence.  And there is no question that the wifi does turn off.

Thanks

title: Avoid scheduling "wifi off" when wifi is already off.
body:
The log reports that app is "Scheduling Wifi to be turned off", "Alarm received" etc, when the screen goes off, even if the wifi is already off.  Seems like a waste.  Not sure if this is logging issue, or actual algorithm issue.

Thanks.

body:
Leaving Wifi on if a whitelisted access point is detected. There are two part to this:
- add 3) to not turn off Wifi if a whitelisted access point is connected to
- add some code handling the state change for losing the connection to this access point as Wifi must then finally be switched off (this can easily be done with the event handler that does loging right now (ConnectionStatshandler).

body:
A "simple" mode would be:
Service setting (all hidden)
Rules for turning Wifi on (all visible)

Rules for leaving Wifi on
Only if connected (on by default but hidden)
Check for cage (off by default but hidden)
If in call (I feel this pref could be removed completely and the behavior aleays be as "on")
If netwotk activity (off by default and hidden)
If wakelock is held (on by default but hidden)
If Wifi tethering (I feel this pref could be removed completely and the behavior aleays be as "on"

Rules whn plugged in
Wifilocks (off by default and hidden)

Rules for turining Wifi off (all on by default and hidden)

Own logfile: not really required as I will provide logcat with grep on BetterWifiOnOff

title: [bug] opening app from notification does not always show event log

[feature] leave Wifi on if a partial wakelock is held
body:
There's a kernel module responsible for creating KWLs on behalf of userland processes. It exposes 2 sysfs entries at /sys/power/wake_lock and wake_unlock.
Any regular process (running as radio or as system) can write to wake_lock to create and lock a KWL with the same name as the passed text. And to unlock it, write the same text to the wake_unlock file.

title: [feature] keep wifi active when data is transferring and screen goes off
body:
Just installed on my TF101 and was updating a load of apps from Google Play. The screen went off, and a few minutes later I unlocked the screen and the WiFi was off (and then reconnected as expected).

It would be nice if the WiFi wouldn't drop when the screen goes off if there is data transferring (over a given threshold I guess), to avoid aborting any downloads that are in progress.

title: [bug] Preference "On only when previously on" work inconsistently
body:
state machine controlled by prefs "wifi_on_when_previously_on" and "last_action"

Goal:
last action shows what was the last thing done by BetterWifiOnOff
if last_action was on 
    but wifi is off that means that the user turned it off -> don't turn on 
if last action was off
    but wifi is on that means that the user turned it on -> don't turn off
